tips.pitfalls: Don't negotiate with yourself at 8pm. The rule stands.

tips.title: The 'Just 10 Minutes' Trick

Adjust themes based on your work patterns
Use weekends for rest or personal projects

tips.title: The 'Immediately Write It Down' Rule
tips.summary: The second a thought or task occurs, write it down. Don't trust 'I'll remember'.
tips.what_happens: Working memory is unreliable. Thoughts vanish seconds after appearing. Writing down immediately captures them.
try_this: Keep a notepad or phone always accessible
The instant something occurs to you, stop and write it
Don't trust 'I'll write it down later' â€” you won't remember
Use voice memos if writing is too slow
Transfer notes to your main system later
tips.why_it_helps: You're externalising memory immediately. Your brain doesn't have to hold onto information.
variations: Use a smartwatch for quick voice notes
Keep sticky notes everywhere
Use a 'brain dump' app (Google Keep, Notion, Apple Notes)
tips.pitfalls: Don't delay. Write it now or it's gone.

tips.title: Visual Reminders Over Mental Ones
tips.summary: Put things where you'll see them. Reminders on doors, sticky notes, objects in your path.

try_this: Put items you need in your path (keys by door, meds by coffee machine)
Use sticky notes on doors, mirrors, or screens
Keep frequently used items visible, not in drawers
Use clear containers for storage
Make reminders impossible to miss
tips.why_it_helps: You're making memory external and visual. You don't have to remember â€” you see it.
variations: Use colour-coding for urgency
Take photos of where you put things
Pin reminders to your phone wallpaper
tips.pitfalls: Don't hide reminders. They only work if you see them.

tips.title: Alarm-Based Reminders
tips.summary: Set alarms for everything you need to remember. Future-you will thank present-you.

try_this: Set alarms for medication, appointments, tasks, leaving times
Label alarms clearly ('Take meds', 'Leave for dentist')
Set multiple alarms if needed (warning + action)
Use different sounds for different types
Don't dismiss alarms â€” act immediately

Pair alarms with calendar events
Use voice assistants (Alexa, Siri) for quick alarms

Every time you come home, put items in their spot

Make the spot visible and accessible
Use baskets, hooks, or trays

Label spots if helpful
Add a checklist: 'Keys? Phone? Wallet?'

tips.title: Chunking Information

Use bullet points instead of paragraphs
Group similar items together
Chunk by meaning or pattern

Review again 1 week later
Use flashcard apps (Anki, Quizlet) with built-in spacing
Focus on retrieval, not re-reading

Test yourself instead of re-reading
Space out practice for skills too

Create visual associations for facts

tips.what_happens: Sleep consolidates memory â€” it moves information from short-term to long-term storage. Poor sleep worsens memory.
try_this: Prioritise 7-9 hours of sleep, especially when learning
Don't pull all-nighters â€” sleep after studying is essential
Nap after learning if possible (even 20 mins helps)
Protect sleep quality (dark room, cool temperature, consistent schedule)
Notice how sleep affects your memory
tips.why_it_helps: You're supporting the biological process of memory formation. Sleep isn't optional for memory.
variations: Review material before sleep (consolidates overnight)
Use sleep tracking to optimise
Address sleep issues (insomnia, apnoea) with a doctor
tips.pitfalls: Don't sacrifice sleep for productivity. You'll remember less, not more.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: Sleep builds memory. I prioritise it.

tips.title: The 'Name Association' Trick
tips.summary: Repeat someone's name immediately, create a visual association. 'Nice to meet you, Sarah.'
tips.what_happens: Names vanish immediately because they're arbitrary. Repetition + association strengthens encoding.
try_this: When introduced, repeat the name immediately: 'Nice to meet you, [Name]'
Create a visual association (rhyme, image, person you know with that name)
Use the name again in conversation within 2 minutes
Write it down if possible
Don't stress if you forget â€” ask again
tips.why_it_helps: You're strengthening encoding at the moment of introduction. Repetition + association = better retention.
variations: Ask for spelling if it helps
Use name tags or seating charts
Take a photo with the person (with permission) and label it
tips.pitfalls: Don't be too hard on yourself. Many people struggle with names.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: I repeat names immediately and create associations.

tips.title: The 'Forgetting Is Okay' Mindset
tips.summary: Forgetting is neurology, not failure. Build systems instead of guilting yourself.
tips.what_happens: Guilt about forgetting worsens memory (stress impairs encoding). Self-compassion + systems work better.
try_this: When you forget, pause and say: 'My brain works differently. I need systems.'
Build external systems (notes, alarms, photos) without shame
Notice when you rely on systems successfully
Share with others: 'I have memory challenges. I use tools to compensate.'
Celebrate systems use, not memory
tips.why_it_helps: You're reducing shame and focusing energy on solutions. Systems work; self-criticism doesn't.
variations: Keep a 'wins' list of times your systems saved you
Educate others about neurodivergent memory
Model system use for others who struggle
tips.pitfalls: Don't blame yourself. Your brain needs support, not judgment.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: Forgetting is neurology. I build systems.

did_you_know: Did you know dyspraxia affects motor planning, not just clumsiness?
Did you know dyspraxia impacts fine motor (writing, buttoning) and gross motor (balance, coordination)?
Did you know proprioception (sensing where your body is in space) is often affected in dyspraxia?
Did you know dyspraxia frequently overlaps with ADHD, dyslexia, and autism?
Did you know dyspraxia can affect speech (verbal dyspraxia) and motor skills?
Did you know sequencing and planning movements is harder for dyspraxic brains?
Did you know dyspraxia isn't something you 'grow out of' â€” but you can learn compensatory strategies?
Did you know fatigue and stress worsen dyspraxia symptoms?
Did you know many people with dyspraxia have slow processing speed for motor tasks?
Did you know dyspraxia can affect handwriting, making it painful or illegible?
Did you know balance and spatial awareness challenges are common in dyspraxia?
Did you know dyspraxia can make learning new physical skills (driving, sports) extremely difficult?
Did you know organisational skills (not just physical) are often impacted by dyspraxia?
Did you know posture and core strength are often weak in dyspraxia, causing pain?
Did you know accommodations (typing instead of writing, extra time) are valid and helpful?

tips.title: Type Instead of Write
tips.summary: Handwriting is painful and slow with dyspraxia. Use keyboards, voice-to-text, or typing for everything.
tips.what_happens: Dyspraxia makes handwriting effortful, painful, and illegible. Typing bypasses fine motor demands.
try_this: Use laptops or tablets for note-taking
Request accommodations for typed assignments or exams
Use voice-to-text when typing is also tiring
Keep handwriting minimal (signature, short forms only)
Don't force handwriting practice â€” typing is valid
tips.why_it_helps: You're removing the motor barrier. Your ideas flow without handwriting slowing you down.
variations: Use stylus + tablet if you prefer drawing to typing
Try ergonomic keyboards or adaptive grips
Use speech-to-text for longer documents
tips.pitfalls: Don't let anyone shame you for not writing by hand. It's a legitimate accommodation.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: Typing is valid. Handwriting is optional.

tips.title: Slip-On Shoes Forever
tips.summary: Tying laces is motor-intensive. Use slip-ons, Velcro, or elastic laces. Save your energy.
tips.what_happens: Tying shoelaces uses fine motor skills and sequencing. Avoiding them saves energy and frustration.
try_this: Buy slip-on shoes, loafers, or Velcro-fastening shoes
Use elastic 'no-tie' laces in existing shoes
Keep shoe choices simple and functional
Don't struggle with laces daily â€” eliminate the task
Choose comfort and ease over style if needed
tips.why_it_helps: You're removing a daily fine motor task. That energy goes elsewhere.
variations: Use zipper boots instead of lace-ups
Teach kids with dyspraxia alternative fastening methods
Use elastic laces in sports shoes
tips.pitfalls: Don't force laces out of habit. Adaptive solutions are smarter.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: Slip-ons save daily energy.

tips.title: Proprioception Grounding
tips.summary: When you feel uncoordinated or 'floaty', do heavy work: push walls, carry weights, press into the floor.
tips.what_happens: Dyspraxia often includes weak proprioception (body position sense). Heavy work (pressure input) helps your brain locate your body.
try_this: Push against a wall with your hands or back for 10 seconds
Carry something heavy (weighted bag, groceries, books)
Press your feet firmly into the floor and notice the pressure
Do wall push-ups or press palms together hard
Use weighted blankets or compression clothing
tips.why_it_helps: You're giving your brain the sensory input it needs to map your body. Proprioception improves with pressure.
variations: Use resistance bands or stretch bands
Try 'body scans' â€” mentally check in with each body part
Wear tight-fitting or compression clothing
tips.pitfalls: Don't ignore feeling 'floaty'. Ground yourself with pressure.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: Heavy work helps me find my body.

tips.title: Break Down Movement Sequences
tips.summary: Multi-step movements are hard. Break them into single steps, practise slowly, repeat.
tips.what_happens: Dyspraxia affects motor sequencing â€” your brain struggles to plan and execute multi-step movements. Breaking them down helps.
try_this: Identify the movement sequence (e.g., putting on a coat: step 1, put one arm in; step 2, pull across back; step 3, put other arm in)
Practise each step separately and slowly
Use verbal cues or write down steps
Repeat until it becomes more automatic
Be patient â€” motor learning takes longer
tips.why_it_helps: You're compensating for sequencing difficulty. Conscious breakdown bypasses automatic planning deficits.
variations: Use video demonstrations slowed down
Mirror someone else doing the movement
Use rhythm or counting to sequence
tips.pitfalls: Don't rush. Slow, deliberate practice is more effective.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: I break movements into single steps.

tips.title: Core Strengthening Gently
tips.summary: Dyspraxia often means weak core and poor posture. Gentle strengthening (Pilates, physio) helps.
tips.what_happens: Weak core muscles lead to poor posture, back pain, and fatigue. Gentle strengthening improves stability.
try_this: Work with a physiotherapist who understands dyspraxia
Try gentle Pilates, yoga, or core exercises
Focus on stabilisation, not intensity
Start with very simple exercises (plank holds, bridges)
Build slowly â€” consistency matters more than intensity
tips.why_it_helps: You're building the foundational strength your body needs. Core stability reduces pain and fatigue.
variations: Use physio apps or videos (search 'core strengthening dyspraxia')
Try swimming or water-based exercises (low impact)
Use a stability ball for sitting
tips.pitfalls: Don't go too hard too fast. Gentle, sustained work is key.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: Gentle core work reduces pain.

tips.title: Pre-Cut or Easy-Prep Foods
tips.summary: Cutting, chopping, and food prep are motor-intensive. Use pre-cut, frozen, or simple foods.
tips.what_happens: Knife skills and food prep require coordination, grip strength, and fine motor control. Simplifying saves energy and prevents injury.
try_this: Buy pre-cut vegetables, fruit, or frozen chopped options
Use kitchen tools: food processors, easy choppers, pre-minced garlic
Choose easy-prep meals (stir-fries with frozen veg, ready-made sauces)
Don't force knife skills â€” safety and ease matter more
Use adaptive cutting boards (with grips or spikes)
tips.why_it_helps: You're removing motor barriers to eating well. Nutrition doesn't require knife skills.
variations: Batch-cook on good coordination days
Ask others to help with prep
Use slow cookers or one-pot meals
tips.pitfalls: Don't risk injury to prove you can. Adaptive tools are smart.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: Easy-prep foods are valid.

tips.title: GPS and Maps Over Memory
tips.summary: Navigation and spatial awareness are hard with dyspraxia. Use GPS without shame.
tips.what_happens: Dyspraxia affects spatial awareness and left-right processing. Getting lost is common. GPS compensates.
try_this: Always use GPS, even for familiar routes
Set GPS before you start driving or walking
Use voice navigation so you don't have to read maps while moving
Plan routes in advance, check them visually
Don't rely on memory or sense of direction
tips.why_it_helps: You're compensating for spatial processing differences. GPS removes the guesswork and stress.
variations: Use augmented reality navigation (Google Maps AR)
Screenshot directions as backup
Leave extra time for wrong turns
tips.pitfalls: Don't try to navigate 'naturally'. Use tools without guilt.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: GPS is always on. No shame.

tips.title: Occupational Therapy Strategies
tips.summary: Work with an OT who understands dyspraxia. Learn adaptive strategies for daily tasks.
tips.what_happens: Occupational therapists specialise in making daily tasks easier. They can assess and suggest personalised strategies.
try_this: Request referral to an OT (through GP, school, or privately)
Focus on functional goals (dressing, cooking, writing, self-care)
Learn adaptive techniques and compensatory strategies
Get recommendations for adaptive equipment
Practise strategies at home
tips.why_it_helps: You're getting expert support tailored to your needs. OT strategies are evidence-based and practical.
variations: Ask for home or workplace assessments
Request adaptive equipment trials
Join dyspraxia support groups for peer strategies
tips.pitfalls: Don't skip OT thinking you 'should manage'. Support is valid.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: OT teaches me adaptive strategies.

tips.title: The 'Sticky Floor' Metaphor
tips.summary: Movement feels like wading through treacle. Rest frequently, don't compare your pace to others.
tips.what_happens: Dyspraxia makes movement effortful and exhausting. Your baseline is slower, and that's okay.
try_this: Acknowledge: 'My body works harder for movement than others'
Rest between physical tasks
Don't compare your pace to non-dyspraxic people
Celebrate what you do accomplish
Use energy-saving strategies (sit instead of stand, break tasks into chunks)
tips.why_it_helps: You're validating your experience and pacing appropriately. Comparison causes shame; acceptance allows adaptation.
variations: Use the 'spoon theory' for physical energy
Plan rest after physically demanding tasks
Communicate your needs to others
tips.pitfalls: Don't push through fatigue. You'll pay with pain and crashes.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: My body works harder. I pace accordingly.

tips.title: Organising Physical Spaces Visually
tips.summary: Use clear containers, labels, and visible storage. 'Out of sight' means lost forever.
tips.what_happens: Dyspraxia overlaps with organisational difficulties and working memory issues. Visible storage helps.
try_this: Use clear plastic containers instead of opaque ones
Label shelves, drawers, and boxes
Keep frequently used items in visible, easy-reach spots
Reduce clutter â€” less stuff = easier to organise
Use open shelving instead of closed cupboards
tips.why_it_helps: You're making organisation visual and intuitive. Seeing items reduces searching and frustration.
variations: Use colour-coding for categories
Take photos of organised spaces to recreate them
Minimise possessions to reduce organisation load
tips.pitfalls: Don't use complex filing systems. Keep it simple and visible.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: Visible storage = findable items.

tips.title: Choose Clothing for Ease
tips.summary: Avoid fiddly fastenings, tight clothing, and uncomfortable textures. Comfort and ease first.
tips.what_happens: Small buttons, zips, and tight clothing are motor and sensory challenges. Adaptive clothing reduces daily struggle.
try_this: Choose elastic waistbands over buttons and zips
Buy shirts with magnetic or large buttons
Avoid clothing that needs complex fastening
Choose soft, comfortable fabrics (avoid scratchy textures)
Prioritise function over fashion if needed
tips.why_it_helps: You're reducing daily fine motor and sensory demands. Getting dressed becomes easier and faster.
variations: Use zipper pulls or button hooks if needed
Buy adaptive clothing designed for easy dressing
Remove tags from all clothing
tips.pitfalls: Don't force uncomfortable or fiddly clothing. Ease matters.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: Easy clothing reduces daily struggle.

tips.title: Driving Adaptations
tips.summary: Driving is hard with dyspraxia. Use automatic transmission, GPS, parking sensors. Extra lessons are okay.
tips.what_happens: Driving requires coordination, spatial awareness, and quick reactions â€” all challenging with dyspraxia. Adaptations help.
try_this: Learn in an automatic car (removes gear-changing complexity)
Use parking sensors and rear cameras
Always use GPS, even for known routes
Take extra lessons if needed â€” there's no shame
Avoid driving when tired or stressed
tips.why_it_helps: You're reducing the motor and spatial demands. Driving becomes safer and less stressful.
variations: Request a specialist driving instructor (some understand dyspraxia)
Practice in quiet areas first
Use adaptive equipment (e.g., spinner knobs for steering)
tips.pitfalls: Don't rush learning. Take the time you need.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: Adaptive driving tools make it safer.

tips.title: Verbal Rehearsal for Movement
tips.summary: Talk yourself through movements: 'Left foot forward, right hand reaches, turn body.' Verbal cues help sequencing.
tips.what_happens: Dyspraxic brains struggle with automatic motor sequencing. Verbal cues provide conscious guidance.
try_this: When learning a new movement, talk yourself through each step
Use simple, clear language: 'Step forward', 'Lift arm', 'Turn left'
Repeat verbal cues as you practise
Over time, the movement may become more automatic
Use this for tricky tasks (parking, tying knots, dressing)
tips.why_it_helps: You're providing external structure for motor planning. Verbal cues bypass automatic sequencing gaps.
variations: Record yourself giving instructions to replay
Ask someone to give you verbal cues
Use rhythm or songs to sequence movements
tips.pitfalls: Don't rush. Slow, verbalised practice is more effective.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: I talk myself through movements.

tips.title: Seated Tasks When Possible
tips.summary: Standing uses energy and balance. Sit for tasks when you can: cooking, showering, getting ready.
tips.what_happens: Standing requires balance and core strength, both challenging with dyspraxia. Sitting conserves energy.
try_this: Use a stool or chair for cooking, washing up, getting ready
Sit on a shower stool or bath edge for washing
Sit to put on shoes and socks
Don't force standing tasks out of habit
Notice how much energy sitting saves
tips.why_it_helps: You're reducing fatigue and balance demands. Sitting makes tasks easier and safer.
variations: Use a perching stool (high stool for kitchen tasks)
Keep seating accessible in every room
Use a rolling chair for tasks that require movement
tips.pitfalls: Don't stand to appear 'capable'. Sitting is adaptive, not lazy.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: Sitting saves energy and balance.

tips.title: Celebrate Effort, Not Perfection
tips.summary: Dyspraxia means movement is harder for you. Celebrate trying, not perfect execution.
tips.what_happens: Dyspraxia makes 'simple' tasks effortful. Perfectionism causes shame. Celebrating effort builds resilience.
try_this: When you complete a motor task (cooking, dressing, navigating), celebrate it
Acknowledge: 'This was hard for my brain and body. I did it anyway.'
Don't compare to others' ease or speed
Notice your effort, not just the outcome
Share your wins with people who understand
tips.why_it_helps: You're validating your experience and building self-compassion. Effort is achievement.
variations: Keep a wins journal
Reframe 'mistakes' as learning
Find dyspraxia communities for mutual support
tips.pitfalls: Don't dismiss your achievements. Dyspraxia makes everything harder â€” you're doing brilliantly.
tips.copy_to_clipboard: Effort is achievement. I celebrate trying.
